title: Alan Ayre-Smith
text:
Alan Ayre-Smith (19 August 1876 – 3 November 1957) was an <a href="England">English</a> international <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> forward who played club rugby for <a href="Guy%27s%2C%20Kings%20and%20St.%20Thomas%27%20Rugby%20Football%20Club">Guy's Hospital</a>. Ayre-Smith played international rugby for the <a href="British%20and%20Irish%20Lions">British Isles</a> team on its <a href="1899%20British%20Lions%20tour%20to%20Australia">1899 tour of Australia</a>.
Personal history.
Ayre-Smith was born in <a href="Richmond%2C%20North%20Yorkshire">Richmond, Yorkshire</a> in 1876 to Dr Robert Ayre-Smith and Catherine Jane Clarke. He married Meta Turnbull and had one son and two daughters. Ayre-Smith was educated at <a href="Durham%20University">Durham University</a>, and gained his degree in Chemistry and Physics. He completed his medical training at <a href="Guy%27s%20Hospital">Guy's Hospital</a> in London. In 1900, as part of the British efforts during the <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Boer War</a>, he travelled to <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a> and worked as a dresser in the Imperial Yeomanry Hospital under <a href="Alfred%20Downing%20Fripp%20%28surgeon%29">Dr Alfred Fripp</a>.
Rugby career.
Ayre-Smith played club rugby for Guy's Hospital, and in 1899 he was selected to join <a href="Matthew%20Mullineux">Matthew Mullineux</a>'s British Isles team on the first official tour of Australia. Ayre-Smith played in 17 of the 20 tour matches and represented Britain in all four Test Matches against <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australia</a>. He played in the opening game of the tour, against Central Southern at <a href="Goulburn%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Goulburn, New South Wales</a>, before the team headed to <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>. There he played against the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Waratahs">New South Wales Waratahs</a>, but missed the game against Metropolitan. Ayre-Smith was back in the team for the First Test, which the British Isles lost, 3-13. Ayre-Smith played in six of the seven invitational games between the First and Second Tests, where he was dropped from the game against <a href="Queensland">Queensland</a>, but scored his first <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">try</a> of the tour in the encounter with Rockhampton. Mullineux reacted to the First Test defeat, by dropping himself from the team, and moving <a href="Charlie%20Adamson">Charlie Adamson</a> in to his vacated half-back position for the Second Test. This was seen as the turning point of the tour and Ayre-Smith was not only part of a winning British team in the Second Test, but also scored his one and only international try during the game. Ayre-Smith played in both the final Test games, both played in Sydney and both resulting in British victories.
